title.narrative: Project Strengthening the Lebanese Water and Agriculture Sector

description.narrative: The Syrian crisis has had serious consequences for Lebanon. More than 1.5 million refugees have found refuge in the country. Meanwhile, the Bekaa Valley, to the east of Lebanon, is experiencing a shortage of drinking water and sanitary facilities. Local agriculture is also suffering from drought conditions. In these challenging circumstances, however, it is of crucial importance that the region be able to achieve good harvests, provide employment and grow its economy. World Waternet, Acacia Water and Wageningen University & Research are working together to support Lebanon using Dutch water and agricultural expertise. The two-year programme was launched in February 2017, with the aim of improving the provision of drinking water, purifying waste water, increasing water availability and boosting farmers’ production by encouraging better, more economical water use.

The programme is part of a larger support programme by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the reception of Syrian refugees in Lebanon as well as the host communities concerned. In addition to activities related to water, the Ministry also supports projects for the improvement of the agricultural sector and the promotion of work opportunities. The aim of this programme is to improve the prospects of both the refugees and their host communities in the region.

The programme’s specifi c components are: 1. Water Operator Partnership (WOP) with Bekaa Water Establishment (BWE). Bringing the Netherlands approach in water governance, expertise in utility management and support to take on waste water treatment as a new task; 2. Water Quality Monitoring Stations Litani River with the Litani River Authority (LRA). Also bringing the Netherlands approach in water governance together with advanced monitoring and data management technologies and in support of the wider Lake Qaraoun Pollution Abatement Project supported by the World Bank; 3. Feasibility mapping small scale storage/ artifi cial recharge and pilot projects with Water Establishments, Ministry of Energy and Water (MoEW) and Green Plan/Ministry of Agriculture. Utilizing advanced Netherlands expertise in artifi cial recharge – a technique that is receiving increased attention in the search for additional water sources in Lebanon – and making it available to Water Establishments; 4. Innovations for investment security in land reclamation and water reservoirs with Green Plan/ Ministry of Agriculture and the Lebanese Agriculture Research Institute (LARI). Bringing advanced Netherlands expertise and technologies in water and agriculture to small scale farmers and their communities; 5. Adaptable greenhouses with the Lebanese Agriculture Research Institute (LARI). Bringing advanced Netherlands expertise in the use of greenhouse techniques adapted to local circumstances and making it available for the broader farmers’ community; 6. The Netherlands Expertise Facility will provide ad-hoc (on-demand) advanced expertise in water and agriculture to Lebanese authorities and international institutions to strengthen the impact of their interventions.
